greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Entry points for the 3-Fibonacci numbers A006190.
comment: a(n) is the smallest k > 0 such that n divides A006190(k).
a(n) is also called the rank of A006190(n) modulo n.
For primes p == 3, 23, 27, 35, 43, 51 (mod 52), a(p) divides p - 1, but a(p) does not divide (p - 1)/2.
For primes p == 7, 11, 15, 19, 31, 47 (mod 52), a(p) divides p + 1, but a(p) does not divide (p + 1)/2.
a(n) <= (12/7)*n for all n, where the equality holds if and only if n = 2*7^e, e >= 1.
link: Jianing Song, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5000
formula: For odd primes p, a(p^e) = p^(e-1)*a(p) if p^2 does not divide a(p). Any counterexample would be a 3-Wall-Sun-Sun prime.
xref: Let {x(n)} be a sequence defined by x(0) = 0, x(1) = 1, x(n+2) = k*x(n+1) + x(n). Then the periods, ranks and the ratios of the periods to the ranks modulo a given integer n are given by:
